bestBHT.bht: Two women shall be grinding together in the same place, near in proximity. The reason for one being taken and the other left cannot be pinpointed to any specific fault or merit, but rather the sovereign will and providence of God, guiding the actions of these men.

Philip Schaff: Luke 17:35. Two women, etc. See on Matthew 24:41.
Luke 17:36 is omitted by the best authorities, and was probably inserted from Matthew 24:40.
Archibald T. Robertson: Periphrastic future active indicative of αληθω, an old verb only in the N.T. here and Matthew 24:41.
Together (επ το αυτο). In the same place, near together as in Acts 2:1.
John Gill: Two [women] shall be grinding together...and at one and the same mill...and it was common for two women to grind at one hand mill..."
The one shall be taken and the other left; the Roman soldiers entering the mill, will lay hold on the one, and carry her away with them, and leave the other..."
...no other reason can be given, but the sovereign will and providence of God, which should overrule and dispose the minds of these men, to act in such a manner.

bhtAttempts.bht: Two women shall be grinding together, in the same place near each other, with one hand mill; and at one and the same mill, one shall be taken and the other left. The Roman soldiers will enter the mill and lay hold on one, carrying her away while leaving the other behind. The reason for this distinction cannot be found in any specific fault or merit on the part of the women, but rather in the sovereign will and providence of God, which directs the actions of these men.

Two women shall be grinding together in the same place, near in proximity. The Roman soldiers will enter the mill and take one woman, leaving the other behind. This distinction is not based on any fault or merit of the women, but solely on the sovereign will and providence of God, which directs the actions of these men.

Two women shall be grinding together in the same place, near in proximity. The reason for one being taken and the other left cannot be pinpointed to any specific fault or merit, but rather the sovereign will and providence of God, guiding the actions of these men.

Two women grinding together at the same mill is the subject of Luke 17:35. The phrase shall be grinding is a periphrastic future active indicative, an old verb used only here and in Matthew 24:41. The women are grinding at the same place, near together, similar to Acts 2:1. In this verse, one woman will be taken and the other left, perhaps by Roman soldiers who will choose to take one woman and leave the other. Such actions can only be attributed to the sovereign will and providence of God, as no other reason can explain their choices.

The future event of two women grinding together at the same mill is mentioned in the quote. This periphrastic future action, found only here and in Matthew 24:41, brings attention to the women's actions. The phrase together, in the same place adds to the description of their proximity. The possibility of Roman soldiers taking one woman and leaving the other is discussed in the quote, with the understanding that their actions are determined solely by God's sovereign will and providence.
